description.raw:
`sdf::convertFile()` and `sdf::convertString()` have a parameter `_toVersion`, but the result is always the latest SDF version. This is because they call an internal method `sdf::readDoc()` after performing a conversion to the target version, and `sdf::readDoc()` always converts a document to the latest version.

This fixes the behavior by adding a parameter `_convert` to `sdf::readDoc()`. If `true` or unspecified the document will be converted to the latest version. If `false`, `sdf::readDoc()` won't do any conversions.

This also adds documentation about the conversion to a few public methods which use `sdf::readDoc()`, and a test which converts from 1.4 to 1.5.
description.html:
sdf::convertFile() and sdf::convertString() have a parameter _toVersion, but the result is always the latest SDF version. This is because they call an internal method sdf::readDoc() after performing a conversion to the target version, and sdf::readDoc() always converts a document to the latest version.

This fixes the behavior by adding a parameter _convert to sdf::readDoc(). If true or unspecified the document will be converted to the latest version. If false, sdf::readDoc() won't do any conversions.

This also adds documentation about the conversion to a few public methods which use sdf::readDoc(), and a test which converts from 1.4 to 1.5.
